The mantle of the Sophist has fallen
on its members. Their feigned ardours
and unreal rhetoric are delightful.
They can make the worse appear
the better cause, as though they were fresh
from Leontine schools,"Ancient schools of rhetoric located in Leontini in Sicily" (Guy 364) and have been known
to wrest from reluctant juries triumphant
verdicts of acquittal for their clients,
even when those clients, as often happens,
were clearly and unmistakeably innocent.
But they are briefed by the prosaic, and
are not ashamed to appeal to precedent.
In spite of their endeavours, the truth will
out. Newspapers, even, have degenerated.
They may now be absolutely relied upon.
One feels it as one wades through their columns.
It is always the unreadable that occurs.
I am afraid that there is not much to be
said in favour of either the lawyer
or the journalist. besides, what
I am pleading for is Lying in
art. Shall I read you what I have
written? It might do you a great
deal of good.

Vivian. For the Retrospective Review. The revival Vivian refers to is an invention. As Josephine Guy notes, "the original Retrospective Review, founded in 180 and runnign until 1828, dealt with historical and antiquarian subjects; a second Retrospective Review--which (according to Evans) consisted of criticism of, and extracts from, curious and rare books--was briefly published in 1853-4 (Evans 295)" (Guy 364).I
think I told you that the electhad
revived it.
Cyril. Whom do you mean by "the elect"?

Vivian. Oh, The Tired Hedonists of course.
It is a club to which I belong. We
are supposed to wear faded roses inroses were frequently associated with Aestheticism, and particularly Walter Pater (usually satirical; see "Mr Rose" by W.H. Mallock in The New Republic. See Guy 364.
